revisions.rev:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Use British English Oxford spelling|date=December 2017}} [[File:International Women's Day 2017 - 03 (33202921961).jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|[[International Women's Day]], London, 2017]] '''Fourth-wave feminism''' is the resurgence of interest in [[feminism]] that began around 2012 and is associated with the use of [[social media]].<ref name=4thWave-Guardian20131210/> According to feminist scholar [[Prudence Chamberlain]], the focus of the fourth wave is justice for women, particularly opposition to [[sexual harassment]] and [[violence against women]]. Its essence, she writes, is "incredulity that certain attitudes can still exist".{{sfn|Chamberlain|2017|p=115}}
Fourth-wave feminism is "defined by technology", according to [[Kira Cochrane]], and characterized particularly by the use of [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]], [[Instagram]], [[YouTube]], [[Tumblr]], and blogs such as [[Feministing]] to challenge [[misogyny]].<ref name="4thWave-Guardian20131210">{{cite news|last=Cochrane|first=Kira|authorlink=Kira Cochrane|title=The Fourth Wave of Feminism: Meet the Rebel Women|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/dec/10/fourth-wave-feminism-rebel-women|newspaper=The Guardian|date=10 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/15/magazine/15fob-q4-t.html|title=The Blogger and Author on the Life of Women Online|last=Solomon|first=Deborah|date=13 November 2009|work=The New York Times|access-date=16 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nowtoronto.com/news/feminisms-fourth-wave-is-the-shitlist/|title=Feminism's Fourth Wave is the Shitlist|last=Zerbisias|first=Antonia|date=16 September 2015|website=NOW Toronto|publisher=|access-date=21 April 2016}}</ref>{{sfn|Cochrane|2013}}
Issues that fourth-wave feminists focus on include [[street harassment|street]] and [[workplace harassment]], [[campus sexual assault]] and [[rape culture]]. Several scandals have galvanized the movement, including the [[2012 Delhi gang rape|Delhi gang rape]] (2012), [[Jimmy Savile sexual abuse scandal|Jimmy Savile allegations]] (2012), [[Bill Cosby sexual assault cases]] (2014), [[2014 Isla Vista killings|Isla Vista killings]] (2014), [[trial of Jian Ghomeshi]] (2016), [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations|Harvey Weinstein allegations]] (2017) and subsequent [[Me Too movement]] and [[Weinstein effect]], and the [[2017 Westminster sexual scandals|Westminster sexual scandals]] (2017).<ref>For Cosby, Ghomeshi, #MeToo and fourth wave, see Matheson, Kelsey (17 October 2017). [http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/kelsey-matheson/you-said-metoo-now-what-are-we-going-to-do-about-it_a_23246129/ "You Said #MeToo. Now What Are We Going To Do About It?"], ''The Huffington Post''.{{pb}} For Savile and fourth wave, see {{harvnb|Chamberlain|2017|pp=114–115}}{{pb}} For Isla Vista killings, see {{cite news|url=http://time.com/3319081/whyistayed-hashtag-feminism-activism/ |title=Behold the Power of #Hashtag Feminism |last=Bennett |first=Jessica |date=10 September 2014 |work=Time|ref=harv}}</ref>
Examples of fourth-wave feminist campaigns include the [[Everyday Sexism Project]], [[Ni una menos]], [[No More Page 3]], [[Stop Bild Sexism]], ''[[Mattress Performance (Carry That Weight)|Mattress Performance]]'', ''[[10 Hours of Walking in NYC as a Woman]]'', [[YesAllWomen|#YesAllWomen]], [[Free_the_Nipple_(campaign)|Free the Nipple]], [[One Billion Rising]], the [[2017 Women's March]], the [[2018 Women's March]], the [[Me Too movement]], and [[Time's Up (movement)|Time's Up]]. In December 2017, [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] magazine chose several prominent female activists involved in the #MeToo movement, dubbed "the silence breakers", as [[Time Person of the Year|Person of the Year]].<ref name=Zacharek6Dec2017/><ref>Redden, Molly, and agencies (6 December 2017). [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/dec/06/metoo-movement-named-time-magazines-person-of-the-year "#MeToo movement named Time magazine’s Person of the Year"], ''The Guardian''.</ref><ref>For page three, see Thorpe, Vanessa (27 July 2013). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/27/new-generation-of-feminists-set-agenda "What now for Britain's new-wave feminists – after page 3 and £10 notes?"], ''The Guardian''.</ref>
== History == {{further|First-wave feminism|Second-wave feminism|Third-wave feminism}} {{Feminism sidebar|expanded=history}} Journalist [[Pythia Peay]] argued for the existence of a fourth wave as early as 2005, one focusing on social justice and civil rights,<ref>{{cite magazine | last=Peay | first= Pythia | title =Feminism's Fourth Wave | work =[[Utne Reader]] | issue = 128 | year = 2005 | pages = 59–60 | url = http://www.utne.com/community/feminisms-fourth-wave.aspx | location = Topeka, Kansas | publisher = Ogden Publications | access-date = 7 October 2017}}</ref> and in 2011 [[Jennifer Baumgardner]] dated the start of the fourth wave to 2008.{{sfn|Baumgardner|2011|p=250}} [[Twitter]], the social network most popular with the 18–29 age group, was created in 2006,<ref>{{Cite web|last=Brodzky|first=Brandon|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/20141118182103-28964915-social-media-user-statistics-age-demographics-for-2014|title=Social Media User Statistics & Age Demographics for 2014|date=18 November 2014|website=LinkedIn Pulse|access-date=16 March 2016}}</ref> making feminism more accessible and giving rise to "hashtag feminism".{{sfn|Bennett|2014}} Cochrane wrote in 2013 that many of the fourth-wave's leaders were teenagers or in their 20s.<ref name="4thWave-Guardian20131210" />
By 2013 it was obvious that a new wave of feminist protests was taking place. When [[Wendy Davis (politician)|Wendy Davis]] staged her 13-hour [[Filibuster in the United States Senate|filibuster]] in Texas in 2013 to prevent an abortion bill from passing, women showed their support by rallying around the [[Texas State Capitol]], and those who couldn't be there physically used the #StandWithWendy. Similarly, women protested the often sexist questions directed at female celebrities by tweeting the hashtag #askhermore.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Chittal|first=Nisha|url=http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/how-social-media-changing-the-feminist-movement|title=How Social Media is Changing the Feminist Movement|website=MSNBC|date=26 March 2015}}</ref>
==Ideas== Cochrane describes the fourth wave as focusing on sexual harassment (including street harassment), workplace discrimination, [[body shaming]], sexist imagery in the media, online misogyny, assault on public transport, and [[intersectionality]], relying on social media for communication and online petitioning for organizing.<ref name="4thWave-Guardian20131210" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Abrahams|first1=Jessica|title=Everything you wanted to know about fourth wave feminism—but were afraid to ask|url=https://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/magazine/everything-wanted-know-fourth-wave-feminism|work=Prospect|date=14 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bcrw.barnard.edu/wp-content/nfs/reports/NFS8-FemFuture-Online-Revolution-Report-April-15-2013.pdf|title=#FemFuture: Online Revolution|last1=Martin|first1=Courtney E.|last2=Valenti|first2=Vanessa|publisher=Barnard Centre for Research on Women|date=15 April 2013}}</ref> Events and organizations included the [[Everyday Sexism Project]], [[Kat Banyard|UK Feminista]], [[Reclaim the Night]], [[One Billion Rising]], and "[[a Lose the Lads' mags protest]]".<ref name="4thWave-Guardian20131210" />
Books associated with the new wave include ''[[Men Explain Things to Me]]'' (2014) by [[Rebecca Solnit]] (which gave rise to the term ''[[mansplaining]]''); ''The Vagenda'' (2014) by [[Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett]] and [[Holly Baxter]] (based on their online feminist magazine, ''[[The Vagenda]]'', launched in 2012); ''Sex Object: A Memoir'' (2016) by [[Jessica Valenti]]; and ''Everyday Sexism'' (2016) by [[Laura Bates]] (based on Bates' Everyday Sexism Project).{{sfn|Bates|2014}} Cosslett's and Baxter's book aims to debunk the stereotypes of femininity promoted by the mainstream women's press.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vagendamagazine.com/about/|title=Letter from the Editor|publisher=The Vagenda|date=19 January 2012}}</ref> Bates, a British feminist writer, created the Everyday Sexism Project on 16 April 2012 as an online forum where women could post their experiences of everyday harassment.<ref name=Aitkenhead24Jan2016>{{cite news |last=Aitkenhead |first=Decca |author-link=Decca Aitkenhead |title=Laura Bates Interview: 'Two Years Ago, I Didn't Know What Feminism Meant' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/24/laura-bates-interview-everyday-sexism |newspaper=The Guardian|date=24 January 2014}}</ref>
== Criticism == One criticism of fourth-wave feminism is that it depends on technology. As [[Ragna Rök Jóns]] argued in ''Bluestockings Magazine'' in 2013, "[t]he key problem that this '4th Wave' will face will be the disproportionate access to and ownership of digital media devices." The fourth wave is left with the "inherent [[classism]] and [[ableism]]" created by giving the biggest voice to those who can afford and use technology.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bluestockingsmag.com/2013/08/19/is-the-4th-wave-of-feminism-digital/|title=Is the '4th Wave' of Feminism Digital?|last=Jóns|first=Ragna Rök|website=Bluestockings Magazine|date=19 August 2013}}</ref>
It is also argued that when people participate in Twitter activism, they may not feel the need to do anything else to help the effort. In an article for [[Newuniversity.org]], Alex Guardado argues that after contributing their say, people just "continue on with their day, liking other posts or retweeting". Some may think of themselves as activists while never bothering to attend a single rally or extend their message beyond their Twitter fan base.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newuniversity.org/2015/03/opinion/hashtag-activism-the-benefits-and-limitations-of-activism/|title=Hashtag Activism: The Benefits and Limitations of #Activism |last=Guardado|first=Alex|date=3 March 2015|work=New University|publisher= University of California, Irvine}}</ref>
[[Jennifer Simpkins]] of ''[[HuffPost|The Huffington Post]]'' argued in 2014 that fourth-wave feminism had created a hostile, ''[[Mean Girls]]''–like atmosphere, in which women are more likely to tear each other down. "I've actually never once been belittled and attacked by a man for believing in the cause of feminism," she states, "but women are just about lining up to take a whack at the shoddy piñata of my personal tastes and opinions."<ref>{{Cite news |last=Simpkins |first=Jennifer |date=20 January 2014 |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/jennifer-simpkins/feminism-fourth-wave-became-mean-girls_b_4616597.html|title='You Can't Sit with Us!' – How Fourth-Wave Feminism Became 'Mean Girls'|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref>
==Timeline== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:95%; width: 90%; text-align:left; float:center; margin-left:10px;" |- ! scope="col" style="width:10em;"|Date ! scope="col" style="width:70em;"|Event ! scope="col" style="width:5em;"|Sources |- |16 April 2012 || [[Laura Bates]] creates the [[Everyday Sexism Project]] for women to report sexist encounters.||<ref name=Aitkenhead24Jan2016/> |- |Aug 2012 ||[[Lucy-Anne Holmes]] starts [[No More Page 3]] to stop ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' in the UK publishing images of topless women.||<ref name=Thorpe27July2013>{{cite web|last1=Thorpe|first1=Vanessa|date=July 27, 2013|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/27/new-generation-of-feminists-set-agenda|title=What now for Britain's new-wave feminists – after page 3 and £10 notes?|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> |- |Sept 2012 || [[Eve Ensler]] founds [[One Billion Rising]] to end sexual violence against women.|| |- |Sept 2012 ||Allegations lead to the [[Jimmy Savile sexual abuse scandal]].|| {{sfn|Chamberlain|2017|pp=114–115}} |- |30 Oct 2012| ||[[Alissa Quart]] coins the term [[hipster sexism]]. || <ref>{{cite web |last=Quart |first=Alissa |author-link=Alissa Quart |date=30 October 2012 |title=The Age of Hipster Sexism |url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2012/10/age-of-hipster-sexism.html |work=New York Magazine |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102054225/http://nymag.com/thecut/2012/10/age-of-hipster-sexism.html |archive-date=2 November 2012|dead-url=no}}</ref> |- |16 Dec 2012|| The [[2012 Delhi gang rape]] sparks protests in India and global outrage.|| |- |2014||[[Free the Nipple (campaign)|Free the Nipple]] argues for women's right to show breasts in public.|| |- |Feb 2013||[[Cao Ju (pseudonym)]], first woman to bring gender-discrimination lawsuit in China, wins 30,000 yuan and apology from the [[Juren Academy]].||<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/chinese-woman-wins-settlement-chinas-first-ever-gender-discrimination-lawsuit-1553018|title=Chinese Woman Wins Settlement in China's First Ever Gender Discrimination Lawsuit|first=Michelle|last=FlorCruz|date=February 3, 2014|work=International Business Times}}</ref> |- |7 March 2013||[[Anita Sarkeesian]] launches [[Tropes vs. Women in Video Games]].|| |- |December 2013||[[Kira Cochrane]]'s book ''All the Rebel Women: The Rise of the Fourth Wave of Feminism'' published. || <ref>{{cite book | last = Cochrane | first = Kira | author-link = Kira Cochrane | title = All the Rebel Women: The Rise of the Fourth Wave of Feminism | publisher = Guardian Books | location = London | url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=UlabBAAAQBAJ | year = 2013 | isbn = 9781783560363}}</ref> |- |22 Jan 2014||[[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama]] launches the [[White House Task Force to Protect Students from Sexual Assault]].|| |- |April 2014||[[Rashida Manjoo]], UN [[Special Rapporteur on Violence Against Women]], criticizes UK's "boys' club sexist culture".|| |- |24 May 2014||[[YesAllWomen|#YesAllWomen]] begins in response to the [[2014 Isla Vista killings]]. || <ref>Grinberg, Emanuella (27 May 2014). [http://www.cnn.com/2014/05/27/living/california-killer-hashtag-yesallwomen/ "Why #YesAllWomen took off on Twitter"], CNN.</ref> |- |Aug 2014||[[Gamergate controversy|Gamergate]] begins, leading to sexist harassment of female video-game developers and widespread condemnation.|| |- |14 Sept 2014||Female graduate student at the [[University of Miami]] reports [[Colin McGinn]] for sexual harassment, sparking debate about sexual harassment within academia.|| |- |20 Sept 2014||[[Emma Watson]] launches [[HeForShe]] at the UN.|| |- |Sept 2014||[[Emma Sulkowicz]] begins ''[[Mattress Performance (Carry That Weight)]]'' to highlight [[campus sexual assault]].|| |- |27 Oct 2014||Release of ''[[10 Hours of Walking in NYC as a Woman]]''.|| |- |Nov 2014||First women speak out about the [[Bill Cosby sexual assault cases|sexual assault by Bill Cosby]].||<ref name=Matheson17Oct2017/> |- |Oct 2014||[[Kristina Lunz]] starts [[Stop Bild Sexism]] to stop the German ''[[Bild]]'' newspaper from objectifying women.|| |- |31 Oct 2014||[[#BeenRapedNeverReported]] tweeted millions of times in response to the [[Jian Ghomeshi]] sexual-assault allegations in Canada.||<ref>Gallant, Jacques (31 October 2014). [https://www.thestar.com/news/crime/2014/10/31/twitter_conversation_about_unreported_rape_goes_global.html "Twitter conversation about unreported rape goes global"], ''Toronto Star''.</ref> |- |Dec 2014||Comic book ''[[Priya's Shakti]]'' features an Indian girl who is gang raped.|| |- |23 Dec 2014||''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine writes that 2014 "may have been the best year for women since the dawn of time".||<ref>Alter, Charlotte (23 December 2014). [http://time.com/3639944/feminism-2014-womens-rights-ray-rice-bill-cosby/ "This May Have Been the Best Year for Women Since the Dawn of Time"], ''Time'' magazine.</ref> |- |22 Sep 2015||Launch of blog [["Breasts Are Healthy"]], to assist women to appear in public bare-chested without police interference. || |- |1 Feb 2016||[[Trial of Jian Ghomeshi]] begins in Toronto.||<ref name=Matheson17Oct2017>Matheson, Kelsey (17 October 2017). [http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/kelsey-matheson/you-said-metoo-now-what-are-we-going-to-do-about-it_a_23246129/ "You Said #MeToo. Now What Are We Going To Do About It?"], ''The Huffington Post''.</ref> |- |21 Jan 2017||[[2017 Women's March]] supports women's rights and protests [[inauguration of Donald Trump]].||<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/01/21/510932265/demonstrators-gather-early-to-kick-off-womens-march-on-washington|title=Women's March Floods Washington, Sparking Rallies Worldwide|newspaper=NPR.org|language=en|access-date=2017-02-05}}</ref> |- |5 October 2017||[[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations]] first reported by ''The New York Times''.|| |- |10 Oct 2017||[[Me Too (hashtag)|#MeToo]] campaign, based on a slogan created in 2007 by [[Tarana Burke]], begins in response to the [[Weinstein effect|Weinstein]] allegations.||<ref name=Matheson17Oct2017/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/20/us/me-too-movement-tarana-burke.html|title=The Woman Who Created #MeToo Long Before Hashtags|first=Sandra E.|last=Garcia|date=20 October 2017|work=The New York Times}}</ref> |- |30 Oct 2017 || The first [[2017 Westminster sexual scandals]] appear on the [[Paul Staines|Guido Fawkes]] blog.|| |- |6 Dec 2017 || ''Time'' magazine names [[Me Too (hashtag)|#MeToo]] campaign as [[Time Person of the Year|Person of the Year]].||<ref name=Zacharek6Dec2017>Zacharek, Stephanie; Dockterman Eliana; and Sweetland Edwards, Haley (6 December 2017). [http://time.com/time-person-of-the-year-2017-silence-breakers/ "The Silence Breakers"], ''Time'' magazine.</ref> |- | 1 January 2018 || [[Time's Up (movement)|Time's Up]], a movement against sexual harassment, is founded by Hollywood celebrities in response to the [[Weinstein effect]] and [[Me Too movement|#MeToo]]. ||<ref>{{cite magazine |date=January 2, 2018 |title=Reese Witherspoon, Taylor Swift, Jennifer Aniston: See Who's Given $500k, More to Fight Harassment |url=http://people.com/movies/reese-witherspoon-taylor-swift-jennifer-aniston-see-whos-given-500k-more-to-fight-harassment/ |magazine=[[People_(magazine)|People Magazine]] |access-date=January 22, 2018}}</ref> |-
|}

Goo Goo, Gaga, and Some Thoughts on Balls|location=Berkeley, California|publisher=Seal Press|isbn=978-1-58005-360-0|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Chamberlain|first=Prudence|year=2017|title=The Feminist Fourth Wave: Affective Temporality|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-3-319-53682-8|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-53682-8|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Cochrane|first=Kira|author-link=Kira Cochrane|year=2013|title=All the Rebel Women: The Rise of the Fourth Wave of Feminism|location=London|publisher=Guardian Books|isbn=978-1-78356-036-3|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|first=Nicola|last=Rivers|title=Postfeminism(s) and the Arrival of the Fourth Wave|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|year=2017|isbn=978-3-319-59812-3|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-59812-3|ref=harv}} {{refend}}
==Further reading== {{refbegin}} *{{cite journal|last=Diamond|first=Diana|year=2009|title=The Fourth Wave of Feminism: Psychoanalytic Perspectives|journal=Studies in Gender and Sexuality|volume=10|issue=4|pages=213–223|issn=1940-9206|doi=10.1080/15240650903228187}} *{{cite journal|last=Munro|first=Ealasaid|year=2013|title=Feminism: A Fourth Wave? |url=https://www.psa.ac.uk/insight-plus/feminism-fourth-wave|journal=Political Insight|volume=4|issue=2|pages=22–25|doi=10.1111/2041-9066.12021}} *{{citebook|last1=Retallack|first1=Hanna|last2=Ringrose|first2=Jessica|last3=Lawrence|first3=Emilie|year=2016|chapter='Fuck Your Body Image': Teen Girls' Twitter and Instagram Feminism in and around School|editor1-last=Coffey|editor1-first=Julia|editor2-last=Budgeon|editor2-first=Shelley|editor3-last=Cahill|editor3-first=Helen|title=Learning Bodies: The Body in Youth and Childhood Studies|volume=2|location=Singapore|publisher=Springer|pages=85–103|doi=10.1007/978-981-10-0306-6_6|isbn=978-981-10-0306-6}} {{refend}} {{feminism}}
